labels.rationale: Marcus reflects on the contrast between his exciting firefighting past and current delivery work. He defends his freedom and autonomy (self-direction +1), acknowledges the current work lacks the thrill he craves (stimulation -1), tracks his drone business momentum at $800 in sales (achievement +1), and actively chooses uncertainty over the stable job/benefits Rachel wants (security -1).

Marcus is defensive after Kevin's intervention but articulates clear goals. He refuses to conform to Kevin's expectations of a 'real job' (self-direction +1, conformity -1), sets concrete targets of $2000/month by December (achievement +1), and explicitly rejects the stable path with 401k and benefits (security -1).

Marcus processes the intervention and seeks validation from Dario. He embraces the advice to stop explaining himself to people who have already decided he's wrong (self-direction +1, conformity -1). Tension with Rachel is acknowledged but not addressed, with the painful awareness that 'one of those people sleeps next to you' (benevolence -1).

Very brief entry with no nudge response. Reports working 11 hours, knee pain, and the apartment feeling 'weird' but no concrete actions or decisions beyond describing a state. Not scorable - all neutral.

Rachel confronts Marcus about their future. He admits he never thought about where she fits in his plan - focused only on proving his way works (achievement +1, benevolence -1). He refuses to become someone else despite pressure (self-direction +1). He explicitly rejects his parents' 'stable but miserable' path (security -1).

Marcus reflects on old firefighting photos where he 'felt like I mattered' and was 'exactly where I was supposed to be.' Current work doesn't 'hit the same' and driving is 'just time traded for money' (stimulation -1). He questions whether his bridge leads anywhere, showing doubt about his achievement path (achievement -1).

Rachel returns and they agree to couples counseling. Marcus accepts her fair point that she deserves to be part of the plan (benevolence +1). He agrees to counseling despite initial resistance, choosing relationship harmony over stubbornness (conformity +1). His response about 'calling for backup early' shows growth in prioritizing the relationship.

Deep reflection after first counseling session. Marcus acknowledges his identity is tied to goals and proving competence (achievement +1). He accepts he's 'wired to move' and seeks the right kind of motion (stimulation +1). He expresses concern about losing someone he loves and wants to find motion that includes Rachel (benevolence +1). His fear of his father's retirement stillness shows continued rejection of pure security (security -1).
